title: Who Is OOMF? Meanings & Variations of OOMF Online

steps.title: â€œOOMFâ€ means â€œone of my followersâ€ or â€œone of my friends.â€
steps.content: â€œOOMFâ€ means â€œone of my followersâ€ or â€œone of my friends.â€ â€œOomfâ€ is a way to call out or drop hints to one of your followers online without naming or mentioning them specifically. It can be used flirtatiously or passive aggressively and is most common on Twitter and TikTok, although it means the same thing on any social media platform. [1] X Research source The acronym first appeared as a hashtag in 2010 and was immediately popular. [2] X Research source â€œoomfâ€™s selfies are looking real fine today ğŸ˜â€ â€œIâ€™m gonna block oomf if they post one more photo of their cat!â€ Use â€œOOMFâ€ with uppercase letters, lowercase letters, or as a hashtag (â€œ#oomfâ€).

steps.title: â€œOOMFâ€ likely just means â€œone of my friendsâ€ over text.
steps.content: â€œOOMFâ€ likely just means â€œone of my friendsâ€ over text. Since your texts arenâ€™t posted publicly and you canâ€™t have text followers, assume â€œoomfâ€ refers to someoneâ€™s real life friend. It could still mean â€œfollowersâ€ if the person youâ€™re texting with is talking about their Twitter or TikTok following specifically, though. Them: â€œWhere are you?â€ You: â€œIâ€™m at oomfâ€™s house.â€ You: â€œoomf told me itâ€™s supposed to rain laterâ€ Them: â€œNoooo!!â€

steps.title: Try â€œoomfieâ€ or â€œcroomfâ€ to put an affectionate spin on â€œOOMF.â€
steps.content: Try â€œoomfieâ€ or â€œcroomfâ€ to put an affectionate spin on â€œOOMF.â€ â€œOomfieâ€ is a flirty way to say â€œoomfâ€ and usually refers to someone you really like or have a crush on. Similarly, â€œcroomfâ€ (â€œcrushâ€ + â€œoomfâ€) means a follower or friend youâ€™re infatuated with. [3] X Research source â€œI hope oomfie likes my vacation photos ğŸ¥ºâ€ â€œIf I am somebodyâ€™s croomf, let me know!â€

steps.title: Use â€œproomfâ€ to talk about followers who can view your private account.
steps.content: Use â€œproomfâ€ to talk about followers who can view your private account. â€œProomfâ€ comes from the words â€œprivateâ€ and â€œoomfâ€ put together. You get to decide who your â€œproomfsâ€ are since youâ€™ll get a notification asking you to accept or decline their follow request . A â€œproomfâ€ has a better chance of figuring out youâ€™re talking about them than a regular â€œoomf.â€ [4] X Research source â€œI tweet my silly little jokes for you, proomfsâ€ â€œIâ€™m about to remove proomf if they keep retweeting cat videos!â€

steps.title: Hint that youâ€™re crushing on a follower with an â€œOOMFâ€ tweet.
steps.content: Hint that youâ€™re crushing on a follower with an â€œOOMFâ€ tweet. Get flirty online and talk about â€œoomfâ€ playfully to get your followers blushing and wondering â€œare they talking about me?â€ If you want your online crush to get the message, drop a detail about something they posted or what they look like and wait for them to slide into your DMs! Use the gender neutral â€œtheyâ€ pronoun to keep things extra vague, or use â€œheâ€ or â€œsheâ€ to be more specific. [5] X Research source â€œoomf is looking mighty cute in their blue hat selfie today ğŸ˜˜â€ â€œoomf keeps tweeting about how no one wants to date him but Iâ€™m right here! hello!!â€

steps.title: Use â€œOOMFâ€ to make neutral comments about your followersâ€™ posts.
steps.content: Use â€œOOMFâ€ to make neutral comments about your followersâ€™ posts. Usually â€œoomfâ€ is used to be flirty or shady, but it can also just be observational. Use â€œoomfâ€ to talk about someoneâ€™s tweet, TikTok video, or other post if you donâ€™t know them well enough to comment on, retweet , or share their content. â€œoomf posted about ice cream today and now I have a craving!â€ â€œugh, oomf tweeted that my favorite singer is coming to town the ONE weekend Iâ€™m gone traveling! ğŸ˜­â€

steps.title: Be shady or passive aggressive towards a follower with â€œOOMF.â€
steps.content: Be shady or passive aggressive towards a follower with â€œOOMF.â€ If someone is irritating you online but you donâ€™t want to engage them directly, broadcast your distaste or threaten to block them with a vague â€œoomfâ€ tweet. This is similar to â€œsubtweeting,â€ or tweeting about someone thatâ€™s bothering you online or in real life (like a roommate, coworker, or in-law) without naming them. [6] X Research source â€œoomf just sent me a GROSS pic of themselves ğŸ¤® Consider this your warning. Youâ€™re blocked next time!â€ â€œMaybe I could afford an impromptu vacay like oomf if my parents paid for it like theirs did ğŸ™„â€ If your follower gets the message, they canâ€™t rebuff you publicly without everyone finding out they were the â€œoomf.â€

steps.title: â€œOOMFâ€ might be a misspelling of the word â€œoomph.â€
steps.content: â€œOOMFâ€ might be a misspelling of the word â€œoomph.â€ â€œOomphâ€ sounds the same as â€œOOMFâ€ when you say it out loud, but it means a specific flair or style someone has that puts their look or work over the edge. If you use â€œoomphâ€ in a tweet, your followers probably wonâ€™t think youâ€™re referring to one of your followers. [7] X Research source â€œI love how she dresses, her looks just have this oomph factor!â€ â€œI could read your writing all day, itâ€™s just OOMPH so goodâ€

steps.title: â€œOOMFâ€ could be an onomatopoeia for a sound someone makes.
steps.content: â€œOOMFâ€ could be an onomatopoeia for a sound someone makes. Onomatopoeia is a rhetorical effect that uses a word to mimic a non-language sound (like â€œcuckooâ€ or â€œsizzleâ€). Someone might let out an â€œoomfâ€ or â€œoofâ€ noise if they bump into something accidentally or notice someone or something they find attractive. â€œI saw Mark at the mall and OOMF he looked good!â€ â€œI wasnâ€™t paying attention and ran into the railing like oomf!â€

steps.title: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms.
steps.content: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms. Learn these popular slang terms to stay in the know and keep your texts looking like English instead of gibberish: BSF : â€œBest sister friendâ€ or â€œbest sibling friendâ€ MMK : â€œMmkayâ€ (a combo of â€œmmâ€ and â€œokayâ€) HB : â€œHeartbroken,â€ â€œhomeboy,â€ or â€œhow â€˜bout?â€ DL : â€œDown lowâ€ ABS : â€œAbsolutelyâ€ WYLL : â€œWhat you look likeâ€ or â€œWhat do you look like?â€ HYB : â€œHow you been?â€ ISTG : â€œI swear to Godâ€
